title: Understanding the Problem
text: Let μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 be the population means of the sororities. Remember that the null hypothesis claims that the sorority groups are from the same normal distribution. The alternate hypothesis says that at least two of the sorority groups come from populations with different normal distributions. Notice that the four sample sizes are each five.
speech: Let μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 be the population means of the sororities. Remember that the null hypothesis claims that the sorority groups are from the same normal distribution. The alternate hypothesis says that at least two of the sorority groups come from populations with different normal distributions. Notice that the four sample sizes are each five.
pacedSpeech: Let μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 be the population means of the sororities. Remember that the null hypothesis claims that the sorority groups are from the same normal distribution. The alternate hypothesis says that at least two of the sorority groups come from populations with different normal distributions. Notice that the four sample sizes are each five.

title: Null and Alternative Hypotheses
text: The null and alternative hypotheses are the following, respectively: $$H_0$$: μ1 $$=$$ μ2 $$=$$ μ3 $$=$$ μ4 and $$H_a$$: Not all of the means μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 are equal.
speech: The null and alternative hypotheses are the following, respectively:    h sub 0 : μ1 , is equal to  μ2  is equal to  μ3  is equal to,  μ4 and    h sub a : Not all of the means μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 are equal.

: Not all of the means μ1, μ2, μ3, μ4 are equal.

title: Test Distribution
text: The distribution for the test: k $$=$$ $$4$$ groups and $$n$$ $$=$$ $$20$$ samples in total where df(num) $$=$$ k - $$1$$ $$=$$ $$4$$ - $$1$$ $$=$$ $$3$$ and df(denom) $$=$$ $$n$$ - k $$=$$ $$20$$ - $$4$$ $$=$$ $$16$$

title: Statistic F
text: The F test statistic is a ratio (a fraction). There are two sets of degrees of freedom: one for the numerator and one for the denominator. To solve for F, find the numerator mean square divided by the denominator mean square, where SS is the sum of squares. Using a calculator, put the data in the table into lists L1, L2, L3, and L4. Press STAT and arrow over to TESTS. Arrow down to F:ANOVA. Press ENTER and Enter (L1,L2,L3,L4). The calculator displays the F statistic, the $$p-value$$ and the values for the one-way ANOVA table.\n##figure1.gif##
speech: The F test statistic is a ratio (a fraction). There are two sets of degrees of freedom: one for the numerator and one for the denominator. To solve for F, find the numerator mean square divided by the denominator mean square, where SS is the sum of squares. Using a calculator, put the data in the table into lists L1, L2, L3, and L4. Press STAT and arrow over to TESTS. Arrow down to F:ANOVA. Press ENTER and Enter (L1,L2,L3,L4). The calculator displays the F statistic, the  p minus value  and the values for the one-way ANOVA table.\n##figure1.gif##

title: Solving for F
text: What is F? Round to the nearest hundredths place.
speech: What is F? Round to the nearest hundredths place.
pacedSpeech: What is F? Round to the nearest hundredths place.

title: Probability Statement
text: What is $$p-value$$ $$=$$ P(F > $$2.23)$$? Round to four decimal places.\n##figure2.gif##
speech: What is  p minus value  , is equal to  P(F >  2.23  ? Round to four decimal places.\n##figure2.gif##

title: Compare 𝛼 and the $$p-value$$
text: Since we are testing at a significance level of 1%, 𝛼 $$=$$ $$0.01$$. The $$p-value$$ $$=$$ $$0.1241$$. If 𝛼 > $$p-value$$, reject $$H_0$$ if 𝛼 < $$p-value$$, accept $$H_0$$.
speech: Since we are testing at a significance level of 1%, 𝛼  is equal to   0.01 . The  p, minus value   is equal to   0.1241 . If 𝛼 >  p, minus, value , reject    h sub 0  if 𝛼 <  p minus, value , accept    h sub 0 .

title: Rejecting or Accepting the Null Hypothesis
text: Is 𝛼 > $$p-value$$ such that you reject the null hypothesis?
speech: Is 𝛼 >  p minus value  such that you reject the null hypothesis?
pacedSpeech: such that you reject the null hypothesis?

title: Conclusion
text: There is not sufficient evidence to conclude that there is a difference among the mean grades for the sororities.
speech: There is not sufficient evidence to conclude that there is a difference among the mean grades for the sororities.
pacedSpeech: There is not sufficient evidence to conclude that there is a difference among the mean grades for the sororities.
